name: James Comerford
comment info:
1. What do you notice? I noticed that people in the 18 to 29 were the group most in favor of college athletes being paid. And as each group get's older in age, they are less in favor of college athletes being paid. This is likely due to younger generations siding with student athletes their age, while older age groups are sticking to more traditional ideas. 

2. What do you wonder? I wonder why so many more men think college athletes should be paid than women. If I had to guess, this might be because men are more likely to be invested in money dominant sports like football and basketball. I also wonder how many people on the graph were athletes in high school and college. I think someones athletic background is essential to this topic, as someone with no interest in sports may not be sure. 

3. What impact does this have you and your community? Even though I don't think I will play competitive sports in college, being a high school athlete has shown me how much dedication and hard work it takes to be an athlete. I have friends and family who are or have played college sports at a high level, and that commitment is on a whole other level. With all the hard work college athletes put in, they deserve to be rewarded.

4. What's going on in the graph? Create a catchy headline that captures the graph's main idea.
The graph is measuring the background and demographics of people who do or do not think college athletes should be paid. 
Should College Athletes be Paid?

name: Claudia Vieira
comment info:
. What do you notice? If your notice makes a claim, wherein the graph is the evidence to support it?

Younger people favor paying college athletes more than older age groups. This is shown with the drastic difference between the age group of 18-29 vs. the age group of 60+.

2. What do you wonder?

Why do the older people who were surveyed not support college athletes being paid? The same type of question for the women who favor athletes not being paid. Why is there such a change between males and females if both participate in college athletics? 

3. What impact does this have on you and your community?

In my community, athletics are highly participated in by age levels ranging from 5-18+. When these sports get more serious in high school years, people may be less inclined to continue them into college if they don't receive payment for them. In some cases, I understand that athletes may receive a full ride or lesser tuition than others. But, this is not the case for every player.

4. What's going on in this graph? Write a catchy headline that captures the graph's main idea.

Payment Is Highly Encouraged by Younger Americans for College Athletics

name: Avonlea Berard
comment info:
1. What do you notice? If your notice makes a claim, where in the graph is the evidence to support it?

I notice that people within the 18-29 age range for the most part strongly agree that college athletes should be paid. As you move up you can notice that this view shifts in the opposite direction, as 60% of participants in the 60 or older age range believe that college athletes should not be paid. I also notice that white people, as well as women, and senior citizens also seem to lean towards the idea of college athletes not being paid.

2. What do you wonder?

I wonder if there are different societal pressures and expectations among all these groups of people and how that may affect their opinions on whether or not college athletes should be paid. I also wonder if racial minorities vote higher on paying athletes due to wage discrimination and the upsetting history that our country has when it comes to the topic of race and pay equality.

3. What impact does this have on you and your community?
While I don’t plan on becoming a college athlete, I have many friends and peers who see themselves playing a sport in college. Payment for college athletes could have an impact on the expenses that they may have to pay for potential injuries as well as helping to minimize the amount of college debt that the student will have to pay off post-college. 

4. What's going on in this graph? Write a catchy headline that captures the graph's main idea.

“College Athletes: Pay or No Play”

name: Teagan Geraghty
comment info:
1. The closer that the participants are, to the age of athletes at the college level, have the least opposition to payments. Specifics are unclear, for what the source of payment is, making the question simpler to dictate a yes-or-no answer upon; it reflects the perspective of how each age group sees this idea. College students are associating money as a benefit, based on the glorification of being paid. The more experience with age, creates the factor of how it may be either unnecessary or lead to other unhealthy habits with money. The older the age group, the less they are for payments. 

2. I wonder if there were specifics or if the question was worded differently, how different groups would respond. For example if they were to make money based on promoting their team on social media, or there was income coming from work that the athletes do in order to benefit the team's fan base and respect. Would this alter all of the responses, or create the same distribution?

3. This relates to sports in my town, as a cluster association for each individual team. They each have their own specific way to make money to by equipment or warm up clothes for games, and they have to find ways to get that profit, it isn't granted by the school aside from the basic needs for the sport.

replies.name: D
replies.comment info: @Teagan Geraghty Thank you for your detailed comment, Teagan!  You have some very insightful ways to think about the graphs and the relationships between the categorical variables.  One interesting thing to consider is the shape description “skewed to the right.”  “Skewed” is a statistical term reserved for describing the shape of a distribution of quantitative data, and the variables analyzed in these graphs are categorical.  As an example, rather than using the description “skewed to the right” for the relationship between age group and opinion, it would be better to describe the “association” between age group and opinion with a statement such as “as age increases, the percent who favor colleges paying athletes decreases.”  Return on Friday when we will release the free link to The New York Times article that includes these graphs.  There, you will be able to read the discussion about who thinks what about paying athletes.

name: Cameron
comment info: The graph for today was made from a Marist poll with 1,264 people involved. Age, race, and gender are all factors in whether they agree if colleges should pay athletes. In our findings, we found that typically the younger the person the more they agree with the idea of paying college athletes. The rates of the vote “yes” drop from 70% (ages 18-29) to 29% (age 60 or older). Another finding we found interesting was the racial and ethnicity graph. There is a considerable difference between people of color and white people if they voted yes or not. One other factor to consider is the gender factor. Unsurprisingly, men voted yes more than women did. There are already many more opportunities for men in the sports field than there arefor women. Everyone knows the wage gap between male and female athletes. All in all, the graph shows us whether certain age groups, genders, and ethnicities agree with the idea of paying college athletes.

name: SophiaV AOSE
comment info: This graph depicts different people's thoughts on whether or not college athletes should be paid. In general, the frequency of answering "yes" decreases with age. name: Sharon Hessney
comment info:
Welcome to Wednesday's live moderation of “What’s Going On in This Graph?”  

Today’s graphs display the February 15 – 21, 2022 Marist poll which asked whether college athletes should be paid.  At issue is whether college athletes are employees of their universities.  Some believe that if athletes were paid, this would encourage athletes to cheat and this would affect sports betting.  

From 9 am – 2 pm E.T. today, share with us your responses online to these three questions -- "What do you notice?”, “What do you wonder?"  and “How will this affect you?”  Plus, please share with us a catchy headline that captures the ideas in these graphs. We look forward to replying to your discoveries.

By Friday morning, we’ll reveal the online article that included these graphs.  

Note that you can get a link to your response (and replies made to it) to share with your teacher and classmates by clicking the response box below your response “Email me when my comment is published.”  

Please visit our archive to see all graphs in this series (tinyurl.com/NYTGraphs).
View our archives that link to all past releases, organized by topic (tinyurl.com/NYTGraphsTopicIndex), 
graph type (tinyurl.com/NYTGraphsTypeIndex) and 
Stat Nugget (tinyurl.com/NYTGraphsStatNuggetsIndex).  

 The next “What’s Going On In This Graph?” will be released by Friday, Nov. 18 with moderation on Wednesday, Nov. 30.  The topic – Covid by Group.

name: Ashley Alv. (P5)
comment info:
1) I see that the poll includes 1,264 adults, all of whom were living in the US. Additionally, I see a tendency among the younger generation to support paying student athletes. This may have its origins in the widely held belief that younger athletes will perform better during the sporting seasons and that these students will bring significant victories to the institutions they represent. However, the elder generation believes that young athletes shouldn't be compensated for their physical abilities. Ethnic groupings also differ significantly from one another.
2) I'm curious as to why so many people think that some racial groups should have more access to employment opportunities than others. Where does the ambiguity surrounding athlete compensation come from? Does the responses to the survey have anything to do with respondents' ages? 3) This is relevant to me and my community because many of the high school athletes, like myself, may have looked for ways to join a college team in order to secure scholarships. name: Mrs. Rategan
comment info:
What we noticed:

Older generations seem to be more in favor of not paying college athletes. Perhaps this is because in their generation, college athletes were not so recognized/paid. More black people say "yes" to college athletes getting paid. Perhaps this is because black people have a harder time working towards becoming an athlete and feel they deserve compensation for their effort. More men agree with college athletes getting paid; perhaps this is because more men play sports than women. Sports tend to be targeted towards males. 

Catchy Titles: 
Wow: How Opinions on Getting Paid for College Sports Reveal Underlying Racism and Sexism in Sports.

name: Charlotte, Block 4
location: Hoggard High School in Wilmington NC
comment info:
The Fiscal Rate of Athleticism
I hear this question float around the room at nearly all thanksgivings, evoking tight responses from each family member. This is what shocked me about the ten percent margin of 60 and older who were unsure, as my 75 year old grandpa seems to have a pretty good idea about it. That's the difference between theoretical and experimental; we base our theories off of our hypothetical experience(opinions), and experiments off of carrying out the hypothesis to the masses. 
For example, I could have theorized Men have a higher "yes" disposition than the Women (who have a higher "Unsure" disposition than men) due to the fact that I'm aware that society associates athleticism with masculinity. Now, just because I'm aware of this doesn't provide data evidence; I would need some sort of chart to prove my point, with percentages and visuals. Information from a chart I read in a textbook that displayed white people as more economically conservative to draw the conclusion that they would have the highest “No” rate when compared to other races.  This would be a good assignment where social studies students had to predict the demographics based on the question and the percentages, using synthesized information from class to apply to modern day polarizing questions.

replies.name: C
replies.location: Hoggard High School in Wilmington NC
replies.comment info:
@Charlotte, Block 4 
"Americans Strongly Favor Money Making Deals for Athletes, Poll Says". The most avid yes group is partly one of the most numerous; gen z, ages 18-29. As an incredibly populous generation, we have an exceeding outreach to the democratic world. While younger people themselves are able to participate in athletics and therefore may be more inclined to it's support, it also has to do with modern media's depiction of athletes and the growing accessibility of multi levels in which sports can be played (rec, club, ecnl, etc.). 

Another demographic extremely close to this 70 percent was black people and latino people, outreaching white people's 34% "yes" rate with a 69% "yes" rate. If we were to piggyback off of the trend with the younger generation and say they were influenced because of their athleticism, it could still be a suggestion as black people of african descent (particularly west african) genetically have more fast-twitch fibers compared to white people. Little research specifies on latinos, making the argument a little wobbly. 
On the flipside, people 60 or older have the highest "no" rate. Is it because they have different priorities, different outlooks on what is worth spending money on? I reflected on this already in my previous comment, picking a factor to be economic conservatism. Saving for retirement is no easy task, and how would a new outflow of money to athletes help?

replies.name: N

replies.comment info:
@N, Block 4 
Before seeing the reveal of the article I knew that 18-29-year-old black and Latino men were most favorable of colleges paying for their athletes. 60+-year-old white women were the least favorable of this poll question. After reading the new information that has come out, I understand more about it. 

The first time I saw the graph I assumed it was about college athletes’ expenses being paid for.  After I read the article I realized the graph was about the NIL policy. This policy is paid to an athlete when they publicly support something, similar to a brand deal. Payments like this end up being controversial because they can mess up an athlete's morals. This policy can cause an athlete to depend on the money from the policy instead of their sport, it’s also easy money. 

I can see how many can disagree with the idea of colleges paying for their athletes. At first thought, this felt like a good thing, but after researching, I’m not as sure. If I received a call asking this question, I wouldn't even consider the policy, but if I knew more about sports I would’ve had a different answer. Those who favored it most likely are more educated about the policy and support it. Those who said no to the question likely didn’t know about the policy or believed it wasn’t right, like me. Before I read this I couldn't figure out the reasoning behind these results, but I now know why people voted the way they did.

name: Avery. Block 4
comment info:
Evidence shows age, race/ethnicity, and gender impacting opinions
From ages 19-29, the youngest age bracket, 70% of people think that colleges should have paid athletes; most likely because they do not have a career or steady paycheck flowing in yet. So, they would not mind having some extra money earned from their talents to fall back on. In fact, my uncle, who was a college athlete 2 years ago, has talked to me about this topic saying that now, as he is trying to get a job, the extra cash would have been a good jump start to a career. But, as age goes up, so does the number of people who disagree with athletes getting paid; by 60+ only 29% of people voted yes. 

In terms of race/ethnicity, 69% of Black athletes voted yes, 69% of Latinx athletes voted yes, and only 34% of White athletes voted yes. This may be because of financial stature, needing to provide for families, or even just due to the number of athletes at these colleges. Finally, there are more men than women who voted yes. This may be due to the number of male vs female athletes or because of inequality. However, there is not enough evidence in this graph to reflect any of the reasons given above; these are just possibilities. 

In my case, I do think that colleges should pay their athletes because of possible situations at home, extra money to help their future, and because they are helping the college earn money. Without the athletes, there would be no games, no revenue, and no earnings for the college.

I notice that as the age increases, the percentage of people who are unsure also increases.

name: Dylan
comment info: I noticed that younger people tend to be more in favor of paying  athletes than older people. I also noticed that black and latino people were more in favor paying athletes than white people. I also noticed that some groups had very few people who were unsure, while other groups, such as people 60 or older, had a lot of people who were unsure. I wonder how they collected the data, did they call people, send them a letter, ask people on the street or some other method.

replies.comment info:
HI, @Dylan --

Learn the methodology of the poll by searching “Marist Sports Betting and Paying College Athletes 2022.”

name: Imani
comment info: One of the biggest trends in the graph is the amount of college-aged people that agree to students being paid to participate in sports. This is because it affects them directly and would provide money for their current schooling, housing, and other commodities that they would need money for. I believe that student-athletes should be paid at least a little because of their dedication to the sport and the fact that they aren't allowed to have a job while in season. As someone who is soon to be considered in the college-aged category, I understand that everything is expensive and money is needed, but at the same time I wonder what would be considered a "good rate" and if your pay counts on how good the team is, if the school is large, or your playtime in-game.

replies.name: A
replies.comment info: @Imani I did not think about how the group if college people has an affect on the graph. I wonder if there was such a large percentage of people who think colleges should pay their athletes because they know more since they see it first hand.

replies.name: N
replies.comment info: @Imani I understand your reasons as to why athletes should be paid by their colleges, and I completely agree with the counter-point you brought up about different “rates” or salaries that athletes would be paid depending on different factors. What tipped me in favor of being against college athletes being salaried is the idea of differing salaries. Some schools may have better offers than others, or some players would be getting paid more than others, and this could cause some problems and for athletes to be motivated by money rather than passion.

name: Chuck
comment info: I notice that as the age studied increases, less people believe that players should be paid by their college. It also shows that minorities and men are primarily the ones that believe that the player should be paid. This data makes me wonder why older whites tend to not want to pay these college players who, other than scholarships, receive no benefit from the University, while the University essentially only gains from taking advantage of the players. My community has an average age of around 30, and my community is generally white, so that means that most people in my community would tend to vote “no.”

replies.name: D
replies.comment info: @Chuck I agree that the previous system was heavily skewed toward colleges. I also think that older people generally tend to be more resistant to change while younger people are more inviting of change.

replies.name: A
replies.comment info: @Chuck I wonder if that first trend is apparent because older people believe that it should be done the old-fashioned way and college players shouldn't get paid because that's how it used to be.

replies.name: N
replies.comment info: @Chuck I agree with your point about the colleges unfairly benefitting from their athletes. Although I would argue that colleges should not pay their athletes, I do believe that most of the time colleges can essentially take advantage of their athletes and monetize them without much compensation for the athletes. It would be interesting to see how much colleges make off of their big-name athletes for the sake of the argument.

name: Finn and Olivia H
comment info: Younger, male, people of color are more likely to agree that colleges should pay their athletes. I wonder if more minorities think athletes should be paid because of the disadvantages they already face in getting recognition and payment for their work and achievements. We don't really see how it relates to our community. Headline:  "Split Views on Paying College Athletes"

replies.comment info:
HI, @Finn and Olivia H --

Have you thought about how much money universities make off sports?  Do you know what this amount is at University of Tennessee and Vanderbilt?  

Who should benefit from money earned by sports?

name: Kel
comment info:
What do you notice? Majority of people, despite the category, think that athletes should be paid by their school. 
What do you wonder? Why is there a higher amount of people saying that female athletes should not be paid?
How does this relate to you and your community? I live in a college town, and the college itself participates in competitive sports. It is intriguing to both students and athletes alike whether or not their peers are being paid for their work.  
What’s going on in this graph? The majority of people believe that students should be paid, but it is not an overwhelming amount. It is still a nuanced discussion.
Create a catchy headline that captures the graph’s main idea. To Pay or Not to Pay, That is the Question.

replies.comment info: @Kel Since the graph does not clearly delineate the relative size of included demographics, there may not necessarily be more people who think that athletes deserve to be paid, but rather more smaller demographics who believe that. It's hard to explain, but I hope that helps.

replies.name: R
replies.comment info: @Kel It's interesting how you think that the graph is referring to the type of athlete. I was under the impression that the graph was who voted, so I find it cool that you thought about it this way :)

name: Adrian
comment info: It seems that Older White Woman are who don't want college athletes to be payed for their extracurricular activities. If that is the case, then I might be an old white woman because college sports are essentially hobbies that are televised.

replies.name: S
replies.comment info: @Adrian Many college athletes are trying to play professional. Personally, that doesn't sound like a hobby and more of an occupation. Don't you think that college athletes that attract so much attention to a school should be paid for their service. The school profits from their name so why shouldn't the athlete receive some of that money.

name: Olivia L
comment info: I noticed that the majority of white old people do not want college athletes to be paid. I wonder about the future of college athletes and if they are still willing to perform while not being paid. This relates to my community because there is a college with many active sports teams in the community. Catch This: Should student athletes be paid or not?

replies.name: S
replies.comment info: @Olivia L Why do older people care so much that college athletes don't get paid? Could it be a level of resentment?

replies.name: I
replies.comment info: @Olivia L Although I agree that older people and white people appear to be the least favorable towards paying college athletes, I think we need to examine this data more closely in order to determine whether it is older white people specifically. As it is currently presented, the data is separated by age, race/ethnicity, and gender, so in order to make claims about groups of people that combine two or more of those categories, we would need to first combine those two sets of data.

name: Marissa
comment info: I noticed that not many people were unsure about whether or not college athletes should be payed, and that a majority of both Black and Latino people in this graph chose yes. I wonder why such a higher percent of Black and Latino people chose yes compared to White people. This graph doesn't really relate to me since I don't care about sports. This graph shows what percentage of different demographics think college athletes should be paid, and a good name for this graph could be "Should College Athletes be Paid?"

replies.comment info: @Marissa Even if you don't care about sports, that does not mean the graph can't be important to you. The issue of paying college athletes, aside from sports, is emblematic of other issues such as unpaid labor, the exploitation of youth, the imbalance of physical activity in educational institutions, and budgeting issues.

replies.name: D
replies.comment info: @Marissa Thank you for your comment, Marissa!  In addition to your other engaging observations, you noticed that the percentage of “unsure” was relatively small.  Why do you think that is?

name: Katy/Anna Grace/Logan
comment info:
What do you notice?
Younger people are more likely to think that college athletes deserve payment.
Men are more likely to think that college athletes deserve payment.
People of white ethnicity are significantly less likely to think college athletes deserve payment.
 
What do you wonder?
Why do women and older people value athletes less than their counterparts?
 
How does this relate to you and your community?
Cookeville TN is very strongly linked to its college and by extension its athletes. Changing the way our university functions would change Cookeville entirely. 
 
What’s going on in this graph? Create a catchy headline that captures the graph’s main idea.
Americans split over the issue of University Athlete Payment

replies.name: D
replies.comment info: @Katy/Anna Grace/Logan I wonder how paying the athletes would change the culture around a team. Would the athletes be more willing to go to smaller schools if they had money or would larger teams further hoard all the talent.

replies.name: M
replies.location: Miami Country Day School in Miami, Fl
replies.comment info: I also noticed less woman think the college athletes should be paid relative to men. I think, in extension of your point, this is very much because of the income disparity that currently takes place in the professional leagues between man and woman. If colleges start paying their athletes, perhaps they will think that male student athletes will be paid more than female student athletes, thus dissuading them from wanting athletes to be paid in general to create optimal equity in sports.

name: Alix
comment info: A high majority of 18-29, Black and Latino, men think colleges should pay their athletes, according to this survey. I believe college athletes should be paid because they are essentially trained, promoted, and profited off from by universities with sufficient athletic programs. I live close to one-and-a-half hours away from the University of Knoxville, and their football team is highly recognized. I believe it would be a disservice to the athletes and resources that go into the programs if the athletes were not properly paid. I also must include that there is a difference in women's and men's college sports and pay. It must be mentioned that, statistically, this graph is not a sufficient representation of the population of any age group, race, or sex because it is a voluntary-response survey.

replies.name: E
replies.comment info: @Alix I agree that college athletes should be paid because the university profits from them, so why shouldn't the athletes get a share as well. I also wonder what a survey would look like if we ask one survey about female athletes and another about male athletes. I wonder if they would differ or be similar. And yes, we do need to keep in considerations that this is a voluntary response survey and there could be some biases.

name: Luclarza
comment info: One thing I observed is how older people say no, and younger people say yes. This may be because they did not get paid in their day, so they don't think that younger people should either. The younger people are still in school and think they deserve to be paid.

replies.name: C
replies.comment info: @Luclarza  I agree that the reason the younger population thinks colleges should pay their athletes is that they are those athletes, while the older generation thinks they should not get paid, not because they didn't get paid in their time but maybe because it does not effect them or anyone they are close with. This could be why the percentage of unsure increases as the age range gets older.

replies.name: E
replies.comment info: @Luclarza I completely agree. I too think that the older demographics might not think it to be fair that athletes get paid because they did not. This may also be because college athletes getting paid brings no benefits to them and does not impact them whatsoever. However, it is important to start somewhere and I do think that college athletes should be paid one day.

replies.name: A
replies.comment info: @Luclarza I agree.

name: Ella
comment info: This is a graph that shows if people think colleges should pay their athletes. When looking at age, it seems that the younger demographic majorly think that athletes should be paid. I suspect this is because college athletes will fall into this category and want to be paid. As the age increases, less and less people argue “yes”. The percentages of unsureness also increases. When looking at race, black people and latinos have the same percentages for “yes”, which is 69%. However, white people have almost half of that percentage. Lastly, for gender, more than half of men think athletes should be paid and about one third of women think the same. I wonder who answered this survey. I also wonder where they and when they did it.

replies.name: K
replies.comment info: @Ella I think that the sample size and location could play greatly into the results of this survey! This is information that I would be very interested in seeing, as well.

replies.name: D
replies.comment info: @Ella Thank you for your comment, Ella!  You noticed some very interesting things.  One thing that is not as easy to see is that the percentage of “unsure” tends to increase with age.  Good catch!  Why do you think that might be?

name: Marsh Wilkerson and Dorian
comment info: Older white demographics tend to believe that the athletes should not be paid. Younger respondents tend to think that athletes should be paid, and minorities especially believe so. I wonder if this is due to the fact that minorities would be more greatly disadvantaged due to being unpaid. A catchy headline could be "The payment of college athletes". It does not relate to our community.

replies.name: C
replies.comment info: @Marsh Wilkerson and Dorian I also noticed how the Black and Latino percentages were the same but wondered why the black percentage had a much higher unsure than the Latino percentages.

replies.name: K
replies.comment info:
@Marsh Wilkerson and Dorian 
I think the athlete discussion in relation to minorities is a very important overlap, since it is much more nuanced than just: "Minorities need money, so they like sports". I think it is very important to highlight these disadvantages in relation to this topic.

name: Cliff
comment info: In this graph, I noticed that the younger generation thinks colleges should pay their athletes, while the percentage of people who think they should increases with age. I also noticed how the percentage of unsure also increases with age. It seems that the black and Latino have the same number of yes votes while the black votes have a larger unsure percentage. Men also have a higher percentage of yes votes than women but a lower unsure amount.

replies.name: M
replies.comment info: @Cliff so true

replies.name: C
replies.comment info: @Cliff I wonder if there is a higher percentage of men that believe colleges should pay their athletes while women have a smaller percentage as well as a larger unsure percentage?

replies.name: O
replies.comment info: @Cliff Hey Cliff! I agree 100% with what you are saying. I like the information you have gathered from the graph. You seem very smart.
